elements.content: Solvothermal treatment of copper(II) salts, ammonia, and 4-cyanopyridine was chosen for the study of supramolecular isomerism of the target binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (4-pytz). A 2D coordination network of α-[Cu(4-pytz)] (1, P21/n, a = 7.9633(5) Å, b = 10.3757(6) Å, c = 13.1054(8) Å, β = 105.673(1)°) was obtained at 120−160 °C using Cu(OH)2 or Cu2(OH)2CO3 as the copper(II) source, while a 3D network of β-[Cu(4-pytz)] (2, Cc, a = 9.4278(5) Å, b = 24.7779(14) Å, c = 10.6761(6) Å, β = 113.025(1)°) was obtained at 100 °C using Cu(OH)2 as copper(II) source. A solvated copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)]·4H2O (3, P21/c, a = 9.2065(8) Å, b = 25.574(2) Å, c = 6.8104(6) Å, β = 90.256(2)°) with 1D coordination structure has also been synthesized at 100 °C using the Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as copper(II) source. Novel hydrogen-bonded water−ammonia ribbons comprised of fused (H2O)5 and (H2O)4(NH3) pentagons were stabilized in the 1D channels of 3. Networks 1 and 2 show structure-related photoluminescence properties, while 3 is nonemissive under UV irritation.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal treatment of copper(II) salts, ammonia, and 4-cyanopyridine was chosen for the study of supramolecular isomerism of the target binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (4-pytz). A 2D coordination network of α-[Cu(4-pytz)] (1, P21/n, a = 7.9633(5) Å, b = 10.3757(6) Å, c = 13.1054(8) Å, β = 105.673(1)°) was obtained at 120-160 °C using Cu(OH)2 or Cu2(OH)2CO3 as the copper(II) source, while a 3D network of β-[Cu(4-pytz)] (2, Cc, a = 9.4278(5) Å, b = 24.7779(14) Å, c = 10.6761(6) Å, β = 113.025(1)°) was obtained at 100 °C using Cu(OH)2 as copper(II) source. A solvated copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)]⋅4H2O (3, P21/c, a = 9.2065(8) Å, b = 25.574(2) Å, c = 6.8104(6) Å, β = 90.256(2)°) with 1D coordination structure has also been synthesized at 100 °C using the Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O as copper(II) source. Novel hydrogen-bonded water-ammonia ribbons comprised of fused (H2O)5 and (H2O)4(NH3) pentagons were stabilized in the 1D channels of 3. Networks 1 and 2 show structure-related photoluminescence properties, while 3 is nonemissive under UV irritation.

elements.content:
A simple binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate system involving in situ ligand synthesis was successfully used to generate one- to three-dimensional coordination architectures.

Introduction

Supramolecular isomerism is an essential element in the context of crystal engineering and structure−property relationship elucidation. Metal−organic architectures constructed by flexible, multifunctional ligands often exhibited structural diversity, but most of them could not be categorized to be true supramolecular isomers for their different chemical compositions. Such phenomena represent the problems of controlling or predicting the superstructure or local coordination environment or even chemical composition of a certain metal−organic system. Therefore, the rational design and controlled synthesis of supramolecular isomers should be regarded as a great achievement in understanding supramolecular isomerism and crystal growth.
elements.clean_text:
A simple binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate system involving in situ ligand synthesis was successfully used to generate one- to three-dimensional coordination architectures.

Introduction

Supramolecular isomerism is an essential element in the context of crystal engineering and structure-property relationship elucidation. Metal-organic architectures constructed by flexible, multifunctional ligands often exhibited structural diversity, but most of them could not be categorized to be true supramolecular isomers for their different chemical compositions. Such phenomena represent the problems of controlling or predicting the superstructure or local coordination environment or even chemical composition of a certain metal-organic system. Therefore, the rational design and controlled synthesis of supramolecular isomers should be regarded as a great achievement in understanding supramolecular isomerism and crystal growth.

elements.content: Recently, we have paid attention to the supramolecular isomerism of binary copper(I) imidazolates and 1,2,4-triazolates. The designed molecular polygons, zigzag chains, and helical chains were obtained in the simplest two-coordinated systems of copper(I) 2-methylimidazolate6 and copper(I) 2-ethylimidazolate, while three different true supramolecular isomers featuring 3D three-connected topologies were also successfully synthesized in the three-coordinated system copper(I) 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazolate. Obviously, the simple two-component-based systems and the simple coordination modes, as well as the limited supramolecular interactions, yielded our prediction of some structural features of these supramolecular isomers. As observed in the copper(I) imidazolates, 0D ring, 1D zigzag, and helical chain were widely encountered in the metal−organic architectures; however, no true supramolecular isomers simultaneously containing all of the above-mentioned three structural types were known before our recent report of a more complicated system, copper(I) 3,5-di(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (2-pytz), in which the ligand has five potential coordination sites.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have paid attention to the supramolecular isomerism of binary copper(I) imidazolates and 1,2,4-triazolates. The designed molecular polygons, zigzag chains, and helical chains were obtained in the simplest two-coordinated systems of copper(I) 2-methylimidazolate6 and copper(I) 2-ethylimidazolate, while three different true supramolecular isomers featuring 3D three-connected topologies were also successfully synthesized in the three-coordinated system copper(I) 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazolate. Obviously, the simple two-component-based systems and the simple coordination modes, as well as the limited supramolecular interactions, yielded our prediction of some structural features of these supramolecular isomers. As observed in the copper(I) imidazolates, 0D ring, 1D zigzag, and helical chain were widely encountered in the metal-organic architectures; however, no true supramolecular isomers simultaneously containing all of the above-mentioned three structural types were known before our recent report of a more complicated system, copper(I) 3,5-di(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (2-pytz), in which the ligand has five potential coordination sites.

elements.content: It should be noted that the copper(I) and the disubstituted 1,2,4-triazolates were in situ generated in the solvothermal treatments of various copper(II) salts, ammonia, and corresponding nitriles. We have successfully trapped the key reaction intermediates, 1,3,5-triazapentadienates, as copper(II) or nickel(II) complexes, using 4-cyanopyridine as the starting nitrile. These intermediates can be further converted to copper(I) and 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (4-pytz) at higher temperatures and in the presence of copper(II) ions. As part of our continuous studies of solvothermal ligand reactions and the supramolecular isomerism of the copper(I) azolates, herein we report the synthesis, structures, and photoluminescence of a new potential supramolecular isomerism system based on binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that the copper(I) and the disubstituted 1,2,4-triazolates were in situ generated in the solvothermal treatments of various copper(II) salts, ammonia, and corresponding nitriles. We have successfully trapped the key reaction intermediates, 1,3,5-triazapentadienates, as copper(II) or nickel(II) complexes, using 4-cyanopyridine as the starting nitrile. These intermediates can be further converted to copper(I) and 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (4-pytz) at higher temperatures and in the presence of copper(II) ions. As part of our continuous studies of solvothermal ligand reactions and the supramolecular isomerism of the copper(I) azolates, herein we report the synthesis, structures, and photoluminescence of a new potential supramolecular isomerism system based on binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate.

elements.content: The 4-pytz ligand is somewhat similar to 2-pytz because they both bear five potential coordination sites, but crystal structure prediction of the binary Cu(4-pytz) should be very different from that of Cu(2-pytz). Commonly, the coordination number of copper(I) is 2, 3, or 4. We could therefore readily expect a two- or three-connected framework for simple (without additional coordination sites) copper(I) imidazolates or triazolates based on a copper(I) to azolate 1:1 stoichiometry, respectivley. On the other hand, we could hardly predict the target structures for the dipyridyl-substituted 1,2,4-triazolates since there are too many possible coordination modes. However, due to the presence of chelating sites, we have successfully predicted that only two coordination modes were reasonable for a binary Cu(2-pytz) system. Such analysis is not available in the Cu(4-pytz) system since the five nitrogen donors are independent. Therefore, some unusual coordination modes or superstructures may be expected for this potential supramolecular isomerism system. With various synthetic methods, we did isolate three new coordination structures α-[Cu(4-pytz)] (1), β-[Cu(4-pytz)] (2), and [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)]·4H2O (3), in which 1 and 2 are true supramolecular isomers with 2D and 3D coordination structures, respectively, and 3 is a solvated copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate hosted novel water−ammonia hybrid ribbon.
elements.clean_text: The 4-pytz ligand is somewhat similar to 2-pytz because they both bear five potential coordination sites, but crystal structure prediction of the binary Cu(4-pytz) should be very different from that of Cu(2-pytz). Commonly, the coordination number of copper(I) is 2, 3, or 4. We could therefore readily expect a two- or three-connected framework for simple (without additional coordination sites) copper(I) imidazolates or triazolates based on a copper(I) to azolate 1:1 stoichiometry, respectivley. On the other hand, we could hardly predict the target structures for the dipyridyl-substituted 1,2,4-triazolates since there are too many possible coordination modes. However, due to the presence of chelating sites, we have successfully predicted that only two coordination modes were reasonable for a binary Cu(2-pytz) system. Such analysis is not available in the Cu(4-pytz) system since the five nitrogen donors are independent. Therefore, some unusual coordination modes or superstructures may be expected for this potential supramolecular isomerism system. With various synthetic methods, we did isolate three new coordination structures α-[Cu(4-pytz)] (1), β-[Cu(4-pytz)] (2), and [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)]⋅4H2O (3), in which 1 and 2 are true supramolecular isomers with 2D and 3D coordination structures, respectively, and 3 is a solvated copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate hosted novel water-ammonia hybrid ribbon.

elements.content: Materials and Physical Measurements. Commercially available reagents are used as received without further purification. [Cu(4-pytap)2] (4-pytap = 2,4-di(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazapentadienate) was synthesized via the method reported by us. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker EQUINOX 55 Fourier transformation infrared spectrometer in the 400−4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Steady-state photoluminescence spectra were measured on a SHIMADZU RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer. Luminescence lifetime measurements were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrometer equipped with a μF900 microsecond flash lamp. In all cases, single crystalline samples were used for the photoluminescence measurements, and the lifetime data were fitted with single or double exponential decay functions. Powder XRD patterns were recorded with Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å) on a RIGAKU D/max 2200 vpc X-ray diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Physical Measurements. Commercially available reagents are used as received without further purification. [Cu(4-pytap)2] (4-pytap = 2,4-di(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazapentadienate) was synthesized  via the method reported by us. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker EQUINOX 55 Fourier transformation infrared spectrometer in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Steady-state photoluminescence spectra were measured on a SHIMADZU RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer. Luminescence lifetime measurements were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrometer equipped with a μF900 microsecond flash lamp. In all cases, single crystalline samples were used for the photoluminescence measurements, and the lifetime data were fitted with single or double exponential decay functions. Powder XRD patterns were recorded with Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å) on a RIGAKU D/max 2200 vpc X-ray diffractometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of α -[Cu(4-pytz)] (1). For method 1, a mixture of Cu(OH)2 (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol) or Cu2(OH)2CO3 (0.22 g, 1.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), and 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 120−160 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with water and ethanol and dried in air to give yellow crystals of 1 in 10−25% yield based on Cu. For method 2, a mixture of [Cu(4-pytap)2] (0.10 g, 0.2 mmol) and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with THF and dried in air to give a yellow powder of 1 in ca. 20% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H8CuN5:  C, 50.43; H, 2.82; N, 24.51. Found:  C, 50.55; H, 2.70; N, 24.39.

For method 2, a mixture of [Cu(4-pytap)2] (0.10 g, 0.2 mmol) and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with THF and dried in air to give a yellow powder of 1 in ca. 20% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H8CuN5: C, 50.43; H, 2.82; N, 24.51. Found: C, 50.55; H, 2.70; N, 24.39.

elements.content: Synthesis of β -[Cu(4-pytz)] (2). A mixture of Cu(OH)2 (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), and 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with water and ethanol and dried in air to give yellow crystals of 2 in 15% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H8CuN5:  C, 50.43; H, 2.82; N, 24.51. Found:  C, 50.37; H, 2.88; N, 24.36.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of  β -[Cu(4-pytz)] (2). A mixture of Cu(OH)2 (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), and 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with water and ethanol and dried in air to give yellow crystals of 2 in 15% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H8CuN5: C, 50.43; H, 2.82; N, 24.51. Found: C, 50.37; H, 2.88; N, 24.36.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu(4-pytz)(NH 3 )] · 4H 2 O (3). A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.48 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol), and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was briefly dried in air to give a large amount of blue crystals of [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] (4-pyCOOH = isonicotinic acid) (>80% yield based on Cu) and pale-yellow crystals of 3 (<5% yield based on Cu; only several milligrams of 3 was manually separated for elemental analysis). Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H19CuN6O4:  C, 38.45; H, 5.11; N, 22.42. Found:  C, 38.62; H, 5.03; N, 22.19.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Cu(4-pytz)(NH  3  )] ⋅ 4H  2  O (3). A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.48 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol), and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was briefly dried in air to give a large amount of blue crystals of [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] (4-pyCOOH = isonicotinic acid) (>80% yield based on Cu) and pale-yellow crystals of 3 (<5% yield based on Cu; only several milligrams of 3 was manually separated for elemental analysis). Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H19CuN6O4: C, 38.45; H, 5.11; N, 22.42. Found: C, 38.62; H, 5.03; N, 22.19.

elements.content: Complex 3 was readily oxidized by air to turn green, while the large single crystals of 1 and 2 were stable toward air. In the TG analyses, 1 and 2 were stable up to 270 and 290 °C, respectively. Meanwhile, no phase transition was observed in the DSC analyses of 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: Complex 3 was readily oxidized by air to turn green, while the large single crystals of 1 and 2 were stable toward air. In the TG analyses, 1 and 2 were stable up to 270 and 290 °C, respectively. Meanwhile, no phase transition was observed in the DSC analyses of 1 and 2.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Data collections of 1−3 were performed with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Complex 3 was protected by expoxy resin coating during data collection since it was not air stable. Absorption corrections were applied by using multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were generated by riding mode (C−H 0.95 Å); hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located from difference maps. The absolute structure of 2 has been determined with the Flack parameter x of 0.018(9). Crystallographic data for 1−3 were summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles were summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text: X-ray  Crystallography. Data collections of 1-3 were performed with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer at T = 293(2) K. Complex 3 was protected by expoxy resin coating during data collection since it was not air stable. Absorption corrections were applied by using multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were generated by riding mode (C-H 0.95 Å); hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located from difference maps. The absolute structure of 2 has been determined with the Flack parameter x of 0.018(9). Crystallographic data for 1-3 were summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles were summarized in Table .

a  Symmetry codes:  a = −x, 1 − y, 1 − z, b = 0.5 − x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 − z for 1; a = x, −y, 0.5 + z, b = 1 + x, y, z, c = −0.5 + x, −0.5 − y, −0.5 + z for 2; a = −x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 − z for 3.

Synthesis. We have reported that low-temperature solvothermal reaction of copper(II) or nickel(II) salts below 100 °C yielded corresponding 1,3,5-triazapentadienates (4-pytap). These 1,3,5-triazapentadienates can be further converted to [Cu(4-pytz)] at higher temperatures in the presence of copper(II) ions. However, preliminary efforts to get large crystals of [Cu(4-pytz)] from [Cu(4-pytap)2] or [Ni(4-pytap)2] were unsuccessful. Fortunately, we could obtain large crystals of α-[Cu(4-pytz)] (1) suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies using a more “traditional” method, that is, one-pot solvothermal reaction of Cu(OH)2 or Cu2(OH)2CO3, aqueous ammonia, and 4-cyanopyridine at 120−160 °C. Moreover, the yellow powder obtained by heating [Cu(4-pytap)2] at 120 °C had a characteristic powder XRD pattern of 1 (Figure S1). To enumerate possible supramolecular isomers of 1, we also tried other synthetic approaches including introduction of different solvents or additives. β-[Cu(4-pytz)] (2) was synthesized using Cu(OH)2 as the copper(II) source at 100 °C (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. We have reported that low-temperature solvothermal reaction of copper(II) or nickel(II) salts below 100 °C yielded corresponding 1,3,5-triazapentadienates (4-pytap). These 1,3,5-triazapentadienates can be further converted to [Cu(4-pytz)] at higher temperatures in the presence of copper(II) ions. However, preliminary efforts to get large crystals of [Cu(4-pytz)] from [Cu(4-pytap)2] or [Ni(4-pytap)2] were unsuccessful. Fortunately, we could obtain large crystals of α-[Cu(4-pytz)] (1) suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies using a more "traditional" method, that is, one-pot solvothermal reaction of Cu(OH)2 or Cu2(OH)2CO3, aqueous ammonia, and 4-cyanopyridine at 120-160 °C. Moreover, the yellow powder obtained by heating [Cu(4-pytap)2] at 120 °C had a characteristic powder XRD pattern of 1 (Figure S1). To enumerate possible supramolecular isomers of 1, we also tried other synthetic approaches including introduction of different solvents or additives. β-[Cu(4-pytz)] (2) was synthesized using Cu(OH)2 as the copper(II) source at 100 °C (Scheme ).

elements.content: Different Synthetic Routes to the Copper(I) 3,5-Di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate
elements.clean_text: 1  Different Synthetic Routes to the Copper(I) 3,5-Di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate

elements.content: It should be mentioned that the reaction products usually exhibited as complicated solid mixtures, but pure 1 or 2 can be easily collected after washing and drying since large crystals of 1 and 2 are very stable toward water and air. The main impurity/byproduct, an easily crashed blue crystalline solid, was determined to be a mononuclear complex, [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] (4-pyCOOH = isonicotinic acid), by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The 4-pyCOO ligand present in this byproduct was generated by hydrolysis of the 4-cyanonitrile. We also noticed that some yellow powder/crystals dissolve or change color in water or air, implying that there were uncharacterized copper(I) complexes produced in the reactions. Indeed, an air-unstable complex [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)]·4H2O (3) was produced along with large amounts of [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] using Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as the copper(II) source at 100 °C upon addition of THF as additional solvent.
elements.clean_text: It should be mentioned that the reaction products usually exhibited as complicated solid mixtures, but pure 1 or 2 can be easily collected after washing and drying since large crystals of 1 and 2 are very stable toward water and air. The main impurity/byproduct, an easily crashed blue crystalline solid, was determined to be a mononuclear complex, [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] (4-pyCOOH = isonicotinic acid), by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The 4-pyCOO ligand present in this byproduct was generated by hydrolysis of the 4-cyanonitrile. We also noticed that some yellow powder/crystals dissolve or change color in water or air, implying that there were uncharacterized copper(I) complexes produced in the reactions. Indeed, an air-unstable complex [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)]⋅4H2O (3) was produced along with large amounts of [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] using Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O as the copper(II) source at 100 °C upon addition of THF as additional solvent.

elements.content: As observed in our reported supramolecular isomerism systems of copper(I) azolates, solvothermal conditions were important for the syntheses of true supramolecular isomers. Since denser structures are more favored under high pressures and high temperatures, the control syntheses of 1 and 2 may be rationalized to be induced by the difference of autogenous pressures. Undesired guest-included products are usually not as stable as the dense binary copper(I) azolates toward water or air. For example, the guest included molecular octagon and decagon of copper(I) 2-methylimidazolate are unstable toward air. In this context, although water showed disadvantages toward the in situ 1,2,4-triazolate formation10 and caused disproportionation of copper(I) complexes, it did play an important role in chemical composition control of the binary copper(I) azolates.
elements.clean_text: As observed in our reported supramolecular isomerism systems of copper(I) azolates, solvothermal conditions were important for the syntheses of true supramolecular isomers. Since denser structures are more favored under high pressures and high temperatures, the control syntheses of 1 and 2 may be rationalized to be induced by the difference of autogenous pressures. Undesired guest-included products are usually not as stable as the dense binary copper(I) azolates toward water or air. For example, the guest included molecular octagon and decagon of copper(I) 2-methylimidazolate are unstable toward air. In this context, although water showed disadvantages toward the in situ 1,2,4-triazolate formation10 and caused disproportionation of copper(I) complexes, it did play an important role in chemical composition control of the binary copper(I) azolates.

elements.content: Crystal Structures. One trigonally coordinated copper(I) ion and one tridentate 4-pytz ligand are revealed in the asymmetric unit of 1 (Figure a). Only the 1- and 2-positions of the triazolato ring, and a pyridyl end, are coordinated to three different copper(I) ions. Similar to most previously reported binary copper(I) triazolates, two copper(I) ions are bridged by the triazolato ring (Cu···Cu 3.498 Å) in a pyrazolate-like mode to give a dinuclear secondary building unit (SBU). From the topological point of view, the copper(I) ions and the 4-pytz ligands can be regarded as three-connected nodes, and the coordination network can be rationalized to be a 2D 4.82 net, equivalent to a 2D (4,4) net regarding the dinuclear SBUs as four-connected nodes (Figure b). The whole 3D structure of 1 is generated by ABAB... stacking of these wavy layers with weak interlayer interactions (Cu···N 2.744 Å) between copper(I) ions and the uncoordinated pyridyl ends.
elements.clean_text: Crystal Structures. One trigonally coordinated copper(I) ion and one tridentate 4-pytz ligand are revealed in the asymmetric unit of 1 (Figure a). Only the 1- and 2-positions of the triazolato ring, and a pyridyl end, are coordinated to three different copper(I) ions. Similar to most previously reported binary copper(I) triazolates, two copper(I) ions are bridged by the triazolato ring (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu 3.498 Å) in a pyrazolate-like mode to give a dinuclear secondary building unit (SBU). From the topological point of view, the copper(I) ions and the 4-pytz ligands can be regarded as three-connected nodes, and the coordination network can be rationalized to be a 2D 4.82 net, equivalent to a 2D (4,4) net regarding the dinuclear SBUs as four-connected nodes (Figure b). The whole 3D structure of 1 is generated by ABAB... stacking of these wavy layers with weak interlayer interactions (Cu⋅⋅⋅N 2.744 Å) between copper(I) ions and the uncoordinated pyridyl ends.

elements.content: Local coordination environments (a) (50%; A = −x, 1 − y, 1 − z; B = 0.5 − x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 − z; C = 0.5 − x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 − z, D = 0.5 − x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 − z, E = 0.5 − x, −0.5 + y, 1.5 − z) and 2D coordination network (b) (uncoordinated pyridyl groups and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity) in 1.

elements.content: There are two copper(I) ions and two 4-pytz ligands in the asymmetric unit of noncentrosymmetric 2. As depicted in Figure a, Cu1 is coordinated to three different 4-pytz ligands, while Cu2 is coordinated to four different 4-pytz ligands. The coordination modes of the two independent 4-pytz ligands are significantly different. Two uncoordinated pyridyl ends of the exo-tridentate pytz are dangling in the free space, in which one pyridyl end was refined as a 2-fold disordered model. On the other hand, two pyridyl groups are coordinated in the exo-tetradentate pytz ligand (Figure a). The interconnection of these three- and four-connected building blocks gives a very complicated 3D network architecture (Figure S3). Since the pyrazolate moieties of the 4-pytz ligands also bridge two copper(I) ions to form a dinuclear SBU, we were able to simplify the coordination network to a uninodal topology regarding the dinuclear SBUs as six-connected nodes (Figure b). This six-connected network is similar to the well-known cubic α-Po net but has an unusual β-Sn topology (Schläfli symbol 485463 and Vertex symbol 4.4.4.4.4.4.4.4.53.53.53.53.*.*.*). So far, a 3-fold interpenetrated example of β-Sn net in the context of coordination polymer was also known.

The coordination modes of the two independent 4-pytz ligands are significantly different. Two uncoordinated pyridyl ends of the exo-tridentate pytz are dangling in the free space, in which one pyridyl end was refined as a 2-fold disordered model. On the other hand, two pyridyl groups are coordinated in the exo-tetradentate pytz ligand (Figure a). The interconnection of these three- and four-connected building blocks gives a very complicated 3D network architecture (Figure S3). Since the pyrazolate moieties of the 4-pytz ligands also bridge two copper(I) ions to form a dinuclear SBU, we were able to simplify the coordination network to a uninodal topology regarding the dinuclear SBUs as six-connected nodes (Figure b). This six-connected network is similar to the well-known cubic α-Po net but has an unusual β-Sn topology (Schläfli symbol 485463 and Vertex symbol 4.4.4.4.4.4.4.4.53.53.53.53.*.*.*). So far, a 3-fold interpenetrated example of β-Sn net in the context of coordination polymer was also known.

elements.content: Local coordination environments (a) (50%; A =x, −y, 0.5 + z; B = 1 + x, y, z; C = −0.5 + x, −0.5 − y, −0.5 + z; D = x, −y, −0.5 + z; E = −1 + x, y, z; F = 0.5 + x, −0.5 − y; 0.5 + z) and the 3D topology (b) in 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Local coordination environments (a) (50%; A =x, -y, 0.5 + z; B = 1 + x, y, z; C = -0.5 + x, -0.5 - y, -0.5 + z; D = x, -y, -0.5 + z; E = -1 + x, y, z; F = 0.5 + x, -0.5 - y; 0.5 + z) and the 3D topology (b) in 2.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one three-coordinated copper(I) ion and one exo-bidentate 4-pytz ligand. In addition to two pyridyl groups offered by two different 4-pytz ligands, an ammonia molecule is involved in the coordination sphere, which is rarely observed in solid-state copper(I) coordination chemistry. Since ammonia has a stronger coordination ability toward copper(I) ion, the Cu−NH3 bond length (2.033(2) Å) in the trigonal coordination configuration of 3 is shorter than the reported Cu−OH2 ones (>2.15 Å) with T-shape coordination environments (Figure S4). The 4-pytz ligands and the copper(I) centers both represent bended linkers to give a polar zigzag chain with all non-hydrogen atoms located in the wavy plane. A wavy layer structure is constructed by alternate stacking of these chains in an antiparallel fashion. The strong hydrogen bonding donors/acceptors are exposed on the layer surface. A water ribbon comprised of fused water pentamers is accommodated in the interlayer channels constructed by translated packing of these wavy layers. It is interesting that this water ribbon is further associated with the ammonia ligand via N−H···O hydrogen bonds to give (H2O)4(NH3) pentagons fused in the water ribbon (Figure ). Although various low-dimensional hydrogen-bonded water networks have been structurally characterized, the structures of mixed water and other small hydrogen bonding molecules have been still rarely reported. Nevertheless, structural elucidation of the supramolecular networks of these hybrids is significant in understanding the unusual properties of these water solutions. As summarized in Table , hydrogen-bonding interactions between the water molecules (O···O 2.712(3)−2.809(3) Å) are much stronger than those between ammonia and water (3.041(3)−3.152(3) Å).

In addition to two pyridyl groups offered by two different 4-pytz ligands, an ammonia molecule is involved in the coordination sphere, which is rarely observed in solid-state copper(I) coordination  chemistry. Since ammonia has a stronger coordination ability toward copper(I) ion, the Cu-NH3 bond length (2.033(2) Å) in the trigonal coordination configuration of 3 is shorter than the reported Cu-OH2 ones (>2.15 Å) with T-shape coordination environments (Figure S4). The 4-pytz ligands and the copper(I) centers both represent bended linkers to give a polar zigzag chain with all non-hydrogen atoms located in the wavy plane. A wavy layer structure is constructed by alternate stacking of these chains in an antiparallel fashion. The strong hydrogen bonding donors/acceptors are exposed on the layer surface. A water ribbon comprised of fused water pentamers is accommodated in the interlayer channels constructed by translated packing of these wavy layers. It is interesting that this water ribbon is further associated with the ammonia ligand via N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds to give (H2O)4(NH3) pentagons fused in the water ribbon (Figure ). Although various low-dimensional hydrogen-bonded water networks have been structurally characterized, the structures of mixed water and other small hydrogen bonding molecules have been still rarely reported. Nevertheless, structural elucidation of the supramolecular networks of these hybrids is significant in understanding the unusual properties of these water solutions. As summarized in Table , hydrogen-bonding interactions between the water molecules (O⋅⋅⋅O 2.712(3)-2.809(3) Å) are much stronger than those between ammonia and water (3.041(3)-3.152(3) Å).

elements.content: Perspective views of a 1D zigzag chain (a), a water−ammonia hybrid ribbon anchored on the 2D wavy layer surface (b), and the 3D host framework of [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)] (c) in 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective views of a 1D zigzag chain (a), a water-ammonia hybrid ribbon anchored on the 2D wavy layer surface (b), and the 3D host framework of [Cu(4-pytz)(NH3)] (c) in 3.

Hydrogen Bonding Parameters of3

D−H···A D···A (Å) ∠DHA (deg) N6−H61···O1 3.041(3) 171(3) N6−H62···O2 3.152(3) 160(3) N6−H63···N1 [x, 0.5 − y, −0.5 + z] 3.445(3) 152(3) O1−H12···O3 [x, y, −1 + z] 2.789(3) 168(4) O1−H11···O4 [x, 0.5 − y, −0.5 + z] 2.712(3) 152(4) O2−H22···N1 [x, 0.5 − y, 0.5 + z] 2.804(3) 168(3) O2−H21···N2 [1 − x, 0.5 + y, 1.5 − z] 2.828(2) 156(3) O3−H31···N3 [1 + x, 0.5 − y, 0.5 + z] 2.897(2) 163(3) O3−H32···O2 2.724(2) 169(3) O4−H42···O1 2.750(4) 169(4) O4−H41···O3 2.809(3) 165(3)

As revealed in the crystal structures of 1−3, the supramolecular isomerism of the Cu(I) 4-pytz system is facilitated by the diverse coordination modes of the 4-pytz ligand (Scheme ).

Photoluminescence. Supramolecular isomers 1 and 2 are strong yellow and green emitters, respectively, whereas 3 is nonemissive under UV excitation. Photoexcitation of 1 and 2 with 368 nm UV light gives structureless emission peaks with maxima at 554 and 532 nm (Figure ), respectively, which can be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer triplet excited states (3[MLCT]) similar to other reported copper(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. The luminescent decay profile of 1 can be fitted with a single-exponential decay function with τ = 320 ns or with a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 300 ns (98%) and τ2 = 1.81 μs (2%) (Figure S5), while that of 2 can only be fitted by a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 66 ns (81%) and τ2 = 298 ns (19%) (Figure S6). The shorter luminescent lifetime of 2 is associated with its loose structure, because its structure bears movable moieties and its crystal density (1.654 g cm-3) is significantly lower than that of 1 (1.821 g cm-3). The two-component excited state of 2 was tentatively assigned to its coordination structure containing two different copper(I) ions and 4-pytz ligands, while the very small contribution of the 1.81 μs component of 1 may be neglected in such an analysis.

 Photoluminescence. Supramolecular isomers 1 and 2 are strong yellow and green emitters, respectively, whereas 3 is nonemissive under UV excitation. Photoexcitation of 1 and 2 with 368 nm UV light gives structureless emission peaks with maxima at 554 and 532 nm (Figure ), respectively, which can be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer triplet excited states (3[MLCT]) similar to other reported copper(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. The luminescent decay profile of 1 can be fitted with a single-exponential decay function with τ = 320 ns or with a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 300 ns (98%) and τ2 = 1.81 μs (2%) (Figure S5), while that of 2 can only be fitted by a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 66 ns (81%) and τ2 = 298 ns (19%) (Figure S6). The shorter luminescent lifetime of 2 is associated with its loose structure, because its structure bears movable moieties and its crystal density (1.654 g cm-3) is significantly lower than that of 1 (1.821 g cm-3). The two-component excited state of 2 was tentatively assigned to its coordination structure containing two different copper(I) ions and 4-pytz ligands, while the very small contribution of the 1.81 μs component of 1 may be neglected in such an analysis.

elements.content: Using a binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate system, we have synthesized two true supramolecular isomers featuring two- and three-dimensional coordination structures. These two isomers also exhibit structure-related photoluminescence properties. A relevant and solvated copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate has also been synthesized and structurally characterized to accommodate a novel mixed water−ammonia hydrogen-bonded ribbon. The role and importance of ligand design and synthetic method toward rational design and understanding of supramolecular isomerism have also been discussed.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Using a binary copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate system, we have synthesized two true supramolecular isomers featuring two- and three-dimensional coordination structures. These two isomers also exhibit structure-related photoluminescence properties. A relevant and solvated copper(I) 3,5-di(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazolate has also been synthesized and structurally characterized to accommodate a novel mixed water-ammonia hydrogen-bonded ribbon. The role and importance of ligand design and synthetic method toward rational design and understanding of supramolecular isomerism have also been discussed.

elements.content: Powder XRD patterns of 1 and 2, packing plot of 2, local coordination environment of 3, luminescence decay profiles of 1 and 2, and X-ray data files in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

Powder XRD patterns of 1 and 2, packing plot of 2, local coordination environment of 3, luminescence decay profiles of 1 and 2, and X-ray data files in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of α -[Cu(4-pytz)] (1). For method 1, a mixture of Cu(OH)2 (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol) or Cu2(OH)2CO3 (0.22 g, 1.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), and 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 120−160 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with water and ethanol and dried in air to give yellow crystals of 1 in 10−25% yield based on Cu. For method 2, a mixture of [Cu(4-pytap)2] (0.10 g, 0.2 mmol) and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with THF and dried in air to give a yellow powder of 1 in ca. 20% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H8CuN5:  C, 50.43; H, 2.82; N, 24.51. Found:  C, 50.55; H, 2.70; N, 24.39.

Synthesis of β -[Cu(4-pytz)] (2). A mixture of Cu(OH)2 (0.19 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), and 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was washed with water and ethanol and dried in air to give yellow crystals of 2 in 15% yield based on Cu. Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H8CuN5:  C, 50.43; H, 2.82; N, 24.51. Found:  C, 50.37; H, 2.88; N, 24.36.

Synthesis of [Cu(4-pytz)(NH 3 )] · 4H 2 O (3). A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.48 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol), and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was briefly dried in air to give a large amount of blue crystals of [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] (4-pyCOOH = isonicotinic acid) (>80% yield based on Cu) and pale-yellow crystals of 3 (<5% yield based on Cu; only several milligrams of 3 was manually separated for elemental analysis). Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H19CuN6O4:  C, 38.45; H, 5.11; N, 22.42. Found:  C, 38.62; H, 5.03; N, 22.19.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.48 g, 2.0 mmol), aqueous ammonia (25%, 3.0 mL), 4-cyanopyridine (1.04 g, 10.0 mmol), and THF (5.0 mL) was sealed in a 15-mL Teflon-lined reactor, heated at 100 °C for 3 days, and slowly cooled to room temperature; the resulting mixture was briefly dried in air to give a large amount of blue crystals of [Cu(4-pyCOO)2(H2O)4] (4-pyCOOH = isonicotinic acid) (>80% yield based on Cu) and pale-yellow crystals of 3 (<5% yield based on Cu; only several milligrams of 3 was manually separated for elemental analysis). Anal. Calcd (%) for C12H19CuN6O4: C, 38.45; H, 5.11; N, 22.42. Found: C, 38.62; H, 5.03; N, 22.19.

cln_elements.content:
Complex 3 was readily oxidized by air to turn green, while the large single crystals of 1 and 2 were stable toward air. In the TG analyses, 1 and 2 were stable up to 270 and 290 °C, respectively. Meanwhile, no phase transition was observed in the DSC analyses of 1 and 2.

As revealed in the crystal structures of 1−3, the supramolecular isomerism of the Cu(I) 4-pytz system is facilitated by the diverse coordination modes of the 4-pytz ligand (Scheme ).

Photoluminescence. Supramolecular isomers 1 and 2 are strong yellow and green emitters, respectively, whereas 3 is nonemissive under UV excitation. Photoexcitation of 1 and 2 with 368 nm UV light gives structureless emission peaks with maxima at 554 and 532 nm (Figure ), respectively, which can be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer triplet excited states (3[MLCT]) similar to other reported copper(I) 1,2,4-triazolates. The luminescent decay profile of 1 can be fitted with a single-exponential decay function with τ = 320 ns or with a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 300 ns (98%) and τ2 = 1.81 μs (2%) (Figure S5), while that of 2 can only be fitted by a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 66 ns (81%) and τ2 = 298 ns (19%) (Figure S6). The shorter luminescent lifetime of 2 is associated with its loose structure, because its structure bears movable moieties and its crystal density (1.654 g cm-3) is significantly lower than that of 1 (1.821 g cm-3). The two-component excited state of 2 was tentatively assigned to its coordination structure containing two different copper(I) ions and 4-pytz ligands, while the very small contribution of the 1.81 μs component of 1 may be neglected in such an analysis.

The luminescent decay profile of 1 can be fitted with a single-exponential decay function with τ = 320 ns or with a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 300 ns (98%) and τ2 = 1.81 μs (2%) (Figure S5), while that of 2 can only be fitted by a biexponential decay function with τ1 = 66 ns (81%) and τ2 = 298 ns (19%) (Figure S6).
